```{r}
# 1.Set up the vector named age 
age <- c(34, 28, 22, 36, 27, 18, 52, 39, 42, 29, 35, 31, 27, 22, 37, 34, 19, 20, 57, 49, 50, 37, 46, 25, 17, 37, 42, 53, 41, 51, 35, 24, 33, 41)

# a. Find the number of data points in the 'age' vector
num_data_points <- length(age)

# Output the number of data points
num_data_points
```

```{r}

# 9. Create a vector from 1 to 100
vec <- seq(100)

result <- Filter(function(i) { all(i %% c(3, 5, 7) != 0) }, vec)

# result
result
```

```{r}
# 11. Generate a vector of natural numbers below 25
numbers <- 1:24

# Find numbers that are multiples of 3 or 5
multiples_of_3_or_5 <- numbers[numbers %% 3 == 0 | numbers %% 5 == 0]

# Sum of multiples
sum_multiples <- sum(multiples_of_3_or_5)

# results
multiples_of_3_or_5
sum_multiples

```

```{r}
# 14. 
# Create the vector
a <- c(1, 2, NA, 4, NA, 6, 7)

# Print the vector with NA values displayed as -999
print(a, na.print = "-999")

#output 
#     2 -999    4 -999    6    7 
#Original Vector: a is c(1, 2, NA, 4, NA, 6, 7). Printing with na.print: NA values are displayed as -999 in the output. The actual vector a stays the same; only how itâ€™s printed is affected.
```
